metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: XML DOM Traverse Node Tree
Traversing means looping through or traveling across the node tree.
content.html: Traversing means looping through or traveling across the node tree.

content.text: Traversing the Node Tree
Often you want to loop an XML document, for example: when you want to extract the value of each element.
content.html: Often you want to loop an XML document, for example: when you want to extract the value of each element.

content.text: This is called "Traversing the node tree"
content.html: This is called "Traversing the node tree"

content.text: The example below loops through all child nodes of <book>, and displays their names and values:
content.html: The example below loops through all child nodes of <book>, and displays their names and values:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var x, i ,xmlDoc;var txt = "";var text = "" + "Everyday Italian" +"Giada De Laurentiis" + "2005" +"";parser = new DOMParser();xmlDoc = parser.parseFromString(text,"text/xml");// documentElement always represents the root nodex = xmlDoc.documentElement.childNodes;for (i = 0; i < x.length ;i++) {    txt += x[i].nodeName + ": " + x[i].childNodes[0].nodeValue + "
";} document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = txt;

// documentElement always 
 represents the root node

syntax_highlighting.text:
var x, i ,xmlDoc;var txt = "";var text = "" + "Everyday Italian" +"Giada De Laurentiis" + "2005" +"";parser = new DOMParser();xmlDoc = parser.parseFromString(text,"text/xml");// documentElement always represents the root nodex = xmlDoc.documentElement.childNodes;for (i = 0; i < x.length ;i++) {    txt += x[i].nodeName + ": " + x[i].childNodes[0].nodeValue + "
";} document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = txt;

// documentElement always 
 represents the root node

content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>

<p id="demo"></p>

<script>
var x, i ,xmlDoc;
var txt = "";
var text = "<book>" +
"<title>Everyday Italian</title>" +
"<author>Giada De Laurentiis</author>" +
"<year>2005</year>" +
"</book>";

parser = new DOMParser();
xmlDoc = parser.parseFromString(text,"text/xml");

// documentElement always represents the root node
x = xmlDoc.documentElement.childNodes;
for (i = 0; i < x.length ;i++) {
    txt += x[i].nodeName + ": " + x[i].childNodes[0].nodeValue + "<br>";
}
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = txt;
</script>

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
var x, i ,xmlDoc;var txt = "";var text = "" + "Everyday Italian" +"Giada De Laurentiis" + "2005" +"";parser = new DOMParser();xmlDoc = parser.parseFromString(text,"text/xml");// documentElement always represents the root nodex = xmlDoc.documentElement.childNodes;for (i = 0; i < x.length ;i++) {    txt += x[i].nodeName + ": " + x[i].childNodes[0].nodeValue + "
";} document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = txt;

// documentElement always 
 represents the root node

content.text: Example explained:
content.html: Example explained:

content.text: Browser Differences in DOM Parsing
All modern browsers support the W3C DOM specification.
content.html: All modern browsers support the W3C DOM specification.

content.text: However, there are some differences between browsers. One important difference is:
content.html: However, there are some differences between browsers. One important difference is:

content.text: DOM - White Spaces and New Lines
XML often contains new line, or white space characters, between nodes. This is often the case when the document is edited by a simple editor like Notepad.
content.html: XML often contains new line, or white space characters, between nodes. This is often the case when the document is edited by a simple editor like Notepad.

content.text: The following example (edited by Notepad) contains CR/LF (new line) between each line and two spaces in front of each child node:
content.html: The following example (edited by Notepad) contains CR/LF (new line) between each line and two spaces in front of each child node:

content.code_html:
<book>
  <title>Everyday Italian</title>
  <author>Giada De Laurentiis</author>
  <year>2005</year>
  <price>30.00</price>
</book>

content.text: Internet Explorer 9 and earlier do NOT treat empty white-spaces, or new lines as text nodes, while other browsers do.
content.html: Internet Explorer 9 and earlier do NOT treat empty white-spaces, or new lines as text nodes, while other browsers do.

content.text: The following example will output the number of child nodes the root element (of books.xml ) has. IE9 and earlier will output 4 child nodes, while IE10 and later versions, and other browsers will output 9 child nodes:
content.html: The following example will output the number of child nodes the root element (of books.xml) has. IE9 and earlier will output 4 child nodes, while IE10 and later versions, and other browsers will output 9 child nodes:

content.code_html:
function myFunction(xml) {
var xmlDoc = xml.responseXML;
    x = xmlDoc.documentElement.childNodes;
    document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML =
    "Number of child nodes: " + x.length;
}

content.text: PCDATA - Parsed Character Data
XML parsers normally parse all the text in an XML document.
content.html: XML parsers normally parse all the text in an XML document.

content.text: When an XML element is parsed, the text between the XML tags is also parsed:
content.html: When an XML element is parsed, the text between the XML tags is also parsed:

content.code_html: <message>This text is also parsed</message>

content.text: The parser does this because XML elements can contain other elements, as in this example, where the <name> element contains two other elements (first and last):
content.html: The parser does this because XML elements can contain other elements, as in this example, where the <name> element contains two other elements (first and last):

content.code_html: <name><first>Bill</first><last>Gates</last></name>

content.text: and the parser will break it up into sub-elements like this:
content.html: and the parser will break it up into sub-elements like this:

content.code_html:
<name>
  <first>Bill</first>
  <last>Gates</last>
</name>

content.text: Parsed Character Data (PCDATA) is a term used about text data that will be parsed by the XML parser.
content.html: Parsed Character Data (PCDATA) is a term used about text data that will be parsed by the XML parser.

content.text: CDATA - (Unparsed) Character Data
The term CDATA is used about text data that should not be parsed by the XML parser.
content.html: The term CDATA is used about text data that should not be parsed by the XML parser.

content.text: Characters like "<" and "&" are illegal in XML elements.
content.html: Characters like "<" and "&" are illegal in XML elements.

content.text: "<" will generate an error because the parser interprets it as the start of a new element.
content.html: "<" will generate an error because the parser interprets it as the start of a new element.

content.text: "&" will generate an error because the parser interprets it as the start of a character entity.
content.html: "&" will generate an error because the parser interprets it as the start of a character entity.

content.text: Some text, like JavaScript code, contains a lot of "<" or "&" characters. To avoid errors script code can be defined as CDATA.
content.html: Some text, like JavaScript code, contains a lot of "<" or "&" characters. To avoid errors script code can be defined as CDATA.

content.text: Everything inside a CDATA section is ignored by the parser.
content.html: Everything inside a CDATA section is ignored by the parser.

content.text: A CDATA section starts with " <![CDATA[ " and ends with " ]]> ":
content.html: A CDATA section starts with "<![CDATA[" and ends with "]]>":

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<script>
<![CDATA[
function matchwo(a,b)
{
   
if (a < b && a < 0) 
   {
           return 1;
       } else
   {
           return 0;
       }
}
]]>
</script>

content.code:
<script>
<![CDATA[
function matchwo(a,b)
{

if (a < b && a < 0)
{
return 1;
} else
{
return 0;
}
}
]]>
</script>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<script>
<![CDATA[
function matchwo(a,b)
{
   
if (a < b && a < 0) 
   {
           return 1;
       } else
   {
           return 0;
       }
}
]]>
</script>

content.code_html:
<script>
<![CDATA[
function matchwo(a,b) {
    if (a < b && a < 0) {
        return 1;
    } else {
        return 0;
    }
}
]]>
</script>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<script>
<![CDATA[
function matchwo(a,b)
{
   
if (a < b && a < 0) 
   {
           return 1;
       } else
   {
           return 0;
       }
}
]]>
</script>

content.text: In the example above, everything inside the CDATA section is ignored by the parser.
content.html: In the example above, everything inside the CDATA section is ignored by the parser.

content.text: Notes on CDATA sections:
content.html: Notes on CDATA sections:

content.text: A CDATA section cannot contain the string "]]>". Nested CDATA sections are not allowed.
content.html: A CDATA section cannot contain the string "]]>". Nested CDATA sections are not allowed.

content.text: The "]]>" that marks the end of the CDATA section cannot contain spaces or line breaks.
content.html: The "]]>" that marks the end of the CDATA section cannot contain spaces or line breaks.
